data.text: Advice and Equipment for Winter Bikepacking

Anyone here done winter bikepacking? In the snow below zero temps. Any suggestions for getting started? Places, trails, gear, general advice? Any issues with the bike at certain temps? I'd love to try it out to see if I can let's say tolerate it and then perhaps work towards enjoying it. I've done a little mountaineering and snow shoeing so I have a taste.
I would suggest pogies. Your fingers (and toes) will be the hardest to keep warm because they cut the wind.
data.author: Dustin Michaels

data.text: Love my Bar Mitts in winter. Also, Wolvhammer boots. As far as the bike goes, road salt will destroy it quickly. So, groomed snowmobile trails would be best. We have a bunch just North in Worlds End State Park. Actually all over "The Endless Mountains" area of North Central PA.

data.text: I’ve done a fair amount of it. I prefer a wax base chain lube in winter since you don’t need to worry about mud. I make my own that has worked well. Pack well and warm, but don’t overdo it. I started out with just panniers but it was too much weight for the floatation so I modified a trailer. A good reliable non-canister stove is a must (MSR Dragonfly is my favorite, unless I’m just boiling water and then the XGK comes out). Forget a water filter and just melt snow, so have a good sized pot. Forget a lantern and just use a headlamp, but bring a book or something, I like movies on my phone with headphones. I agree on the pogies, and the Bar Mitts are ok, but others are worth the extra (I have 45NRTH). A solid insulating ground pad is better but takes up real estate.

data.text: No bugs, no mud, and very very few people. Just some thoughts for you to consider: If you backpack in the fall you probably have enough gear. Sleeping bags are delta °T gear, a rated to 32°F bag is good for 65°-32°= 33°delta T, so a second 40° bag should be good down to 33-25= aprox 10°F. Two fall bags and polar fleece top and pants should be good for 0°F. Hat for head and no more than an inch of cheap closed cell foam and your set. Keep your boots in a bag inside your sleeping bag. Tarps and ground cloth is fine, if tenting leave doors open or frost will accumulate in the inside. When it’s really cold I don’t bother with fires. Rain is your real enemy, I still use a poncho in the winter, better ventilation than any “breathable” material, and cheap. Because it gets dark early I am in no rush to cook and continue to use my titanium twig stove to cook/heat soup, etc. I do bring a flashlight but for meal prep I like my 1960s candle lantern. I use a cheap plastic sled to drag my gear in. You will need snow shoes. (I’ve got 5 pair) I’ve camped in very cold temps -32°F in the 1960swith my crazy Dad and -42°f in Labrador more recently. Practice in your back yard - try meal prep first then sleeping. (I sleep on my side with a fist firmly planted under my chin to keep my mouth closed, to minimize loss of water and heat. (Mouth breathing makes me very thirsty) If it is very cold only my nose is semi exposed. I’ve tried the hot water bottle in the sleeping bag…big deal only stays warm for a while. If you really like it you will eventually get a very warm sleeping bag, (mine is rated for -65°F and I’ve had it since 1967.) If out for more than 2 nights I use a vapor barrier liner to keep my bag from moisture evaporating from my body.

data.text: That’s what I have. At times it’s brute force to maintain a speed faster than walking. But it’s all great. On my bike I’m more for packing with low volume and don’t worry about weight. For time in camp to keep warm I spend most of my time in my sleeping bag, at least one of them. 9 out of 10 trips are solo, helps when I’ve got only two speeds —- biking and stopped wearing a sleeping bag, no fires and asleep by 6 PM. (I pack up, bike to get warmed up, stop for Breakfast, bike, stop for main meal bike, stop-snack and bed. I do the same when hiking, canoeing(flat water) or kayaking mixed flat water and up to class ll WW. I would not dare keep the 2 meal schedule this other companions.) Because nothing spoils winter meals include plenty of steak, no eggs - to hard to cook when frozen. And I will repeat the a most important procedure is stay dry and boots in your sleeping bag. It will take literally hours to thaw frozen boots while wearing them. If you want to hear crazy, I’ve made winter speed runs on snowshoes wearing running shoes and gators- 14 miles a day.
